headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the McCormick's Fourth Quarter 2009 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Joyce Brooks, Vice President, Investor Relations for McCormick. Thank you, Ms. Brooks, you may begin.
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the McCormick's Fourth Quarter 2009 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Joyce Brooks, Vice President, Investor Relations for McCormick. Thank you, Ms. Brooks, you may begin.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning to everyone on today's call and to those joining us by webcast. The purpose of our call is to review McCormick's fourth quarter financial results, achievements in 2009 and guidance for 2010. We have posted a set of slides to accompany today's
componenttext: Good morning to everyone on today's call and to those joining us by webcast. The purpose of our call is to review McCormick's fourth quarter financial results, achievements in 2009 and guidance for 2010. We have posted a set of slides to accompany today's call at our website, ir.mccormick.com. With me are: Alan Wilson, Chairman, President and CEO; Gordon Stetz, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Paul Beard, Senior Vice President, Finance and Treasurer. Following our remarks, we look forward to discussing your questions.As a reminder, our presentation today contains projections and other forward-looking statements, and actual results could differ materially from those projected. The company undertakes no obligation to update or revise publicly any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or other factors. In addition, information we present today, which excludes restructuring charges, as well as unusual items recorded in 2008, are not GAAP measures, and we present this information for comparative purposes, alongside the most directly comparable GAAP measures. Reconciliations of GAAP to non-GAAP measures can be found in this morning's press release and in the presentation slides for our call. Note that we do not expect to record any restructuring charges in 2010. It is now my pleasure to turn the discussion over to Alan.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joyce. And I'd like to welcome everyone on this call as well. I'll begin with comments about our business performance for the fourth quarter and fiscal year, then Gordon will provide more insights and the financial results for the quarter and I'll
componenttext: Thanks, Joyce. And I'd like to welcome everyone on this call as well. I'll begin with comments about our business performance for the fourth quarter and fiscal year, then Gordon will provide more insights and the financial results for the quarter and I'll wrap up with our outlook for further growth in 2010.Due to the seasonality of our business at McCormick, the fourth quarter of the fiscal year is historically a big part of our annual profit results and an even larger part of our cash flow. The most recent fourth quarter was no exception. Strong financial results led to a record year in profit and cash flow for 2009. Taking a look at Slide 4, on a comparable basis with the fourth quarter of 2008, we grew earnings per share 8%, sales growth and margin improvement were key drivers. This year, we had our largest holiday marketing program ever in support of our seasonal items, including spices, herbs, gravies and holiday essentials here in the United States. We also increased marketing this quarter behind our consumer favorites such as Vahiné dessert items in France and behind new products, such as honey jams in China. While we grew Consumer sales 4% in the fourth quarter, sales in our Industrial business continued to be hampered by moderation in new product innovation by food manufacturers and continued pressure on the food service industry. We were pleased to deliver another quarter of increased operating income for our Industrial business, which was up 6% on a comparable basis excluding restructuring charges and unusual items. On the same basis, we increased operating income for our Consumer business 12%. These results were driven largely by progress with CCI, our Comprehensive Continuous Improvement program. Cash flow from operations in the fourth quarter was particularly strong, exceeding our expectations with further achievements and working capital management.Turning to results for fiscal year 2009 and Slide 5, excluding restructuring charges, we achieved earnings of $2.35 per share and reached a record $416 million in cash flow from operations. We were particularly pleased with the cash results, since this was well in excess of the previous high of $342 million. Excluding restructuring charges and unusual items, earnings per share of $2.35 was a 10% increase from the prior year and above our latest guidance of 8% to 9%. This was our fourth consecutive year of double-digit EPS growth on a comparable basis. With 100-basis-point improvement in gross profit margin, we surpassed our 50-basis-point goal for the year. Another area of excellent achievement was in cost reductions, which totaled $42 million for the year, 40% ahead of our initial 2000 goal, and we reduced our cash conversion cycle by five days at the top-end of our three-to-five-day target. This is a total reduction of 10 days since 2007, bringing our cash conversion cycle down by more than 10%.Now let's talk about sales growth, which is the one area that came in below our expectations. We grew sales 5% in local currency. This increase was mainly due to incremental sales from Lawry's, which we're right on target. However, the sales growth in our base business lagged our expectations, hampered by the impact of the economy on our customers and consumers. In 2009, food retailers faced heightened competition and an economically constrained consumer. Certain retailers responded by placing more emphasis on their private label products during the year while others, including dollar stores and hard discounters, chose to expand their branded offerings. The net effect of these actions was some share loss of our spices and herbs products to private label during 2009. However, we were able to grow sales of our branded spices and seasonings at retail with our marketing support and new product innovations.  As seen the Slide 6, based on retail scanner data, consumer purchases of our products were up in each of our four largest geographic markets in 2009. Inventory reductions by food retailers also impacted sales growth in our major markets. During 2009 the growth in consumer purchases at retail exceeded the growth rate for our net sales of spices and seasonings as shown on Slide 7. Likewise, our Industrial customers were affected by tough economy in 2009. While we had some great new product winds early in the year, and success in lowering cost for this part of our business, sales to Industrial customers had slowed by the fourth quarter. Among our Industrial customer groups, quick-service restaurants fared relatively well and our sales to this channel was the best performing part of our Industrial business in 2009. This performance was lagged by sales to food service distributors which serve higher-end restaurants and institutions. We also had a disruption from the bankruptcy of our U.K. distributor.As for food manufacturers, 2009 was a year when many of these customers focused on core items, with limited activity behind innovation and a fair amount of SKU reduction. At this time, we are encouraged by an increased in activity in 2010 and our innovation pipeline. We continue to have strong win rates on new products. For both Consumer and Industrial businesses, 2009 marked the period of further volatility and in both input cost and currency. Our sourcing teams worked to minimize the profit impact of higher cost and our pricing actions provided an effective offset, which accounted for about 4% of sales growth for the year. However, the stronger dollar was a real headwind to our reported sales growth in 2009 reducing sales by 5% for the year. By the fourth quarter, the impact of currency was neutral and at today's exchange rates should provide a bit of a tailwind in the first half of 2010.With changes underway by our customers, costs and currency volatility and consumers still under pressure, our business leaders were agile in addressing these challenges and pursuing opportunities for growth. We also stayed focused on several key initiatives. Job number one in 2009 was a seamless integration of Lawry's. Looking back on the work of our team, this has been one of our most effective integration efforts. Our new marketing campaign has been underway for more than six months now and I'm encouraged by the year-on-year growth achieved in the fourth quarter with unit sales up 8%. Based on results to date for sales, profit and cash, this has been a very successful acquisition at McCormick. In 2009, we increased our brand marketing support by $20 million and our spending is now up more than 50% in the last five years. During this year, we optimized the spending by adapting the current market conditions. To address the actions of various retailers behind the assortment of brand and private label in our core categories, we worked directly and diligently with many major retailers to optimize product mix, pricing and promotion for both brand and private labels.In addition to emphasize the value of our brands, we directed a portion of our promotion and advertising to coupons and feature prices in both the U.S. and certain international markets. Consumers have responded with our coupon redemption rates up more than 50% in the U.S. and branded sales growth in most major markets as I showed earlier. Doing part of more online advertising, traffic to our U.S. website exceeded 200 million visits last year. Following the relaunch of our UK Schwartz site, an increase in advertising search activity hit rates in October and November doubled versus the previous year. These consumers are actually spending an average of about seven minutes of each visit. On Slide 12, a portion of our marketing supported many of our consumer favorites and grew up sales. Our revitalized McCormick brand dry seasoning mixes grew 6% in the U.S, outpacing the increase in private label. Grill Mates sales were up 20%. In Australia, higher sales of slow cooker seasonings led to 3.5% share gain in the Recipe Mix category and Aeroplane gelatin sales rose 14%.Our promotion and advertising also featured some of our newer items such as Lawry's reduced sodium seasoning, honey jams in China and Schwartz flavorful products in the UK. Pâtissierie Vahiné in France is an extension of our leading brand of dessert items to a range of cake mixes. In just over a year, we've gained a 6% share of the Cake Mix category in France with these new items and our marketing campaign. Together with our marketing efforts, innovation helped drive category growth in our four largest markets that's shown in units on Slide 14. New product wins on the industrial side of our business, including condiments, as well as seasonings for chicken and seasonings for snacks.In 2009, we continued to expand the geographic footprint for the McCormick brand in China. And in the last two years have doubled the number of major cities where consumers can purchase our products. During this period, we also gained new distribution with value-priced retailers in the U.S., Canada and France. Another key initiative behind our success was cost reduction. Our process reliability program, coupled with the McCormick high-performance work system have unleashed capacity in all of our major locations. We have successfully completed our restructuring program which began in late 2005. This initiative has enabled us to reduce the number of major facilities by 26% and increased our sales per facility by 66%.In 2009, we also made great progress with CCI and it's illustrated on Slide 16. Employees in all parts of the business contributed to the substantial cost reductions achieved. In addition, we have made impressive results from a sustainability standpoint. Our largest production facility in the U.K. was named Sustainable Manufacturer of the Year by a leading manufacturing publication, in recognition of a 14% reduction in electricity usage and a 48% increase in recycling. A new recycling unit in our Atlanta, Georgia plant contributed to a 43% solid waste reduction for this facility. Across all major facilities, we've reduced greenhouse gases by 24%, water usage by 19% and electricity usage by 14% since 2005.  While the 2009 profit results of our unconsolidated income declined in U.S. dollars, we have impressive results from our largest and long-standing joint venture, McCormick de Mexico, which grew sales 19% in local currency. As a sign of the consistent and steady performance at McCormick, the Board approved in November an 8% increase in the quarterly dividend. This marked the 24th consecutive year of increases in our shareholder dividends. I hope that these latest achievements in our 2009 financial results give you a sense of the talent and energy of our employees. We have a wonderful culture and high-employee engagement and we were pleased to be named just last week, the Fortune Magazine's 100 Best Companies to Work For list. Before discussing our outlook for 2010, Gordon is going to provide you with some further insights into our fourth quarter financial results and business performance.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alan. As previously stated, our fourth quarter results were a strong finish to the year. On a comparable basis, fourth quarter earnings per share rose 8%, with an underlying increase in each of our two segments. On this same basis, we achieved the
componenttext: Thanks, Alan. As previously stated, our fourth quarter results were a strong finish to the year. On a comparable basis, fourth quarter earnings per share rose 8%, with an underlying increase in each of our two segments. On this same basis, we achieved the double-digit increase in Consumer business' operating income, which rose 12%, including the impact of higher brand marketing support and a solid 6% increase in industrial operating income. Just as we had for the full year, we saw areas of both strength and weakness in the quarter for our two segments. For the Consumer business, we increased the operating income $17 million on a comparable basis. This includes a $5 million increase in marketing support for the quarter, which totaled $6 million for both business segments. We grew operating income with sales growth and cost savings from CCI, as well as with a favorable business mix. Keep in mind that we closed the acquisition of Lawry's in the third quarter of 2008 and there is no incremental impact on this acquisition in fourth quarter results.For the total Consumer segment on Slide 23, sales rose 4% in the fourth quarter, with pricing up 3% and a 1% benefit from foreign currency exchange rates. As a reminder, our pricing actions in the Consumer business occurred late in 2008 and early in 2009 in order to offset higher costs. At this time, the impact of pricing actions for our Consumer business in 2010 are expected to be minimal. For Consumer sales in the Americas, the increase was 5%, with 2/3 from pricing and 1/3 from volume and product mix. This quarter, our largest unit increases in the U.S, for dry seasoning mixes, up 5%; Lawry's items, up 8%; McCormick-branded spices and herbs, up 5%; and grilling products, up 16%, evidence that grilling has truly become a year-round event.Sales for each of these product lines was driven by greater marketing support, which included television, print, Internet and coupons. Offsetting some of the strengths were declines in unit sales of our gourmet line. For our Europe, Middle East and Africa region, EMEA, we reported a 1% increase in Consumer sales. However in local currency, sales were down 2%. A 2% benefit from pricing was more than offset by lower volume and product mix.Through the fourth quarter, our business in France continued to be of benefit from healthy category growth for our Ducros spices and seasonings, as well as our growth initiatives behind Vahiné dessert items. However, the retail environment in the U.K. continues to be challenging and affected our fourth quarter sales in this market. In the Asia Pacific region, we reported a 15% increase in Consumer sales. In local currency, the increase was 7%, with higher volume and product mix, the primary driver. In China, our geographic expansion in new product activity, as well as a portion of our incremental marketing, led to this increase. Let's turn to the Industrial business. We increased fourth quarter operating income 6% on a comparable basis. In the quarter where segment sales declined, this profit increased as evidence of our effectiveness, CCI-driven savings and careful cost management. Also, the majority of new products added to our portfolio in 2009 are accretive to the overall margins. Across all regions, Industrial sales declined 2% and were down 1% in local currency. Pricing actions to reflect input cost changes added 2% of sales, while volume and product mix were unfavorable. In the Americas, Industrial sales were down 4% and down 2% in local currency. This is a reversal from the performance in earlier quarters during 2009. We continued to benefit from new product activity with quick-service restaurants but saw a lower demand from food manufacturers during this period. Our relationships with these strategic partners remain strong and they remain committed to McCormick as a supplier.In EMEA, we achieved sales growth with Industrial customers through the end of 2009. Sales were up 2% and up 6% in local currency, primarily as a result of the pass-through pricing for higher costs. In the Asia Pacific region, we saw a slowdown in demand from the restaurant customers during this period. Industrial sales in the fourth quarter were down 2% and down 6% in local currency as a result of unfavorable volume and product mix. In China, our customers have focused on core menu items in recent months and their pace of innovation slowed in the fourth quarter.Let's look at how this adds up to the total business. Sales rose 2%, primarily as a result of higher pricing, with the pluses and minuses of volume and product mix across our segments and regions having a minimal impact on this quarter's sale. Gross profit this quarter rose 190 basis points to a seasonally strong 45.6%, due in part to our move toward a more favorable business mix. Our margin improvement is also being driven by CCI, as well as our restructuring actions and discretionary cost controls throughout our operations.Turning to Slide 29, SG&A in the fourth quarter of 2009 was 25.8% of net sales, an increase of 30 basis points. A $6 million increase in brand marketing added 60 basis points. This increase was offset in part by our progress with CCI and cost controls, as well as lower distribution costs and favorable benefit expenses. Operating income reached $178 million. On a comparable basis, excluding restructuring charges, we increased operating income 11% in the fourth quarter versus the year-ago period.Our tax rate for the quarter at 33.6% brought our fiscal year rate to 31.9%, which reflected our mix of business. We expect our tax rate in 2010 to also be close to 32%. Today's 67% increase, income from unconsolidated operations this quarter showed a dramatic turnaround from the year-to-date declines we had been reporting. As Alan shared, our joint venture in Mexico has had strong sales all year. In the fourth quarter, with the weaker U.S. dollar and lower soybean oil cost, we saw a significant profit growth from this business. We are looking for further gains in 2010 and expect to reach or exceed the level of profitability reported in 2008.If you look at the bottom line, shows fourth quarter earnings per share of $0.87 compared to $0.62 last year. In the fourth quarter of 2008, we recorded restructuring charges and an impairment charge that had lowered EPS by $0.22. In 2009, restructuring charges lowered EPS by $0.04. Excluding these items, EPS increased 8% or $0.07 to $0.91 from $0.84 in the prior year. Higher operating income added $0.10 per share. Lower net interest expense added $0.01 and the income from unconsolidated operations added $0.02, offset in part by $0.06 from an increased tax rate.Before turning I turn it back over to Alan, I'll comment briefly on the balance sheet and cash flow and refer you to Slide 32. Beginning in 2008, we began to reward our business leaders, not only for strong operating income performance but also for their management of working capital. In our second year at McCormick Profit, we are growing both profit and cash. With a further improvement in the fourth quarter, cash flow from operations reached $416 million, an increase of $101 million from 2008. This increase has been driven by higher net income, including the positive impact of Lawry's, as well as effective working capital management. Alan shared with you already our continued progress in compressing our cash conversion cycle which now stands at just above 80 days. Keep in mind that our cash flow from operations includes an increase in pension contributions. In 2009, we contributed $72 million versus $19 million in 2008. This brought our funded level for the primary U.S. pension plan back above 90%, based on the accumulated benefit obligation liability. At this time, we anticipate contributions in 2010 of approximately $45 million. About half of this amount was funded in early December. As we discussed last quarter, 2010 pension expense is expected to increase substantially, due primarily to changes in the actuarial assumptions, primarily the discount rate. We now expect pension expense to be approximately $27 million in 2010, compared to $13 million in 2009. The increase from 2009 to 2010 is expected to reduce EPS by $0.07, approximately 3%. Note that our cash flow will benefit from the lower expected contributions and that the increase in pension expense is a non-cash item. I'll conclude my comments on the balance sheet and cash flow by pointing to our great progress with debt reduction. As you know, our primary use of cash during 2009 has been the reduction of debt from the Lawry's acquisition. This focus approach in strong cash generation has allowed us to reduce our debt by $252 million during 2009. Our priorities for uses of cash, as we head into 2010, will be to reduce debt and fund potential acquisitions, as well as fund dividend payments in an estimated $100 million in capital expenditures. In a few minutes, I'll look forward to discussing your questions. But I first want to turn it back over to Alan.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gordon. We're excited about our prospects for growth in 2010. While we expect our customers, both Consumer and Industrial customers, to be operating under continued pressure during a gradual economic recovery, we are seeing more appetite for innov
componenttext: Thanks, Gordon. We're excited about our prospects for growth in 2010. While we expect our customers, both Consumer and Industrial customers, to be operating under continued pressure during a gradual economic recovery, we are seeing more appetite for innovation. There's some clear path platforms for growth in our business around health and wellness, convenience, authentic ethnic flavors and value. In 2010, these platforms direct our product innovation for both Consumer and Industrial businesses, as well as our marketing support. As we stated earlier, we have high win rates with our Industrial customers and an innovation pipeline that includes new products for food manufacturers in the food service channel. As discussed in our last call, the new product line up for our U.S. Consumer business, includes Perfect Pinch and Recipe Inspirations, which both did very well in test markets during 2009. We've received some early support for Recipe Inspirations from consumer trends experts, Phil Lempert, who discovered this product and has included it in his food industry remarks in ABC, Supermarket Guru, The View, and more recently on the Today Show. He commented, "This is going to pave the way for other similar concepts that will expand our palate." We've had an unprecedented reaction from our customers with 14 key grocery requesting early shipments on Recipe Inspirations in anticipation of strong consumer demand. We are introducing new varieties in McCormick brand dry seasoning mixes and Lawry's marinades and will be extending our range of products imported from our joint venture in Mexico through our line of popular teas. In Canada, we are revitalizing our Club House brand core spices, featuring new labeling, new products and media advertising. Consumers in Europe will see a U.K. version of Perfect Pinch and new varieties of our Schwartz flavorful range. In France, we're expanding our line of Vahiné cake mixes and decorations. And our team in Australia is introducing a line of slow cooker seasonings for rice. In 2010, we're also going to seize the opportunity to increase marketing support behind our leading brand and new products to capture consumer interest, as they continue to prepare meals at home. We're getting a good value for our marketing dollars when purchasing advertising. And then the U.S. and Europe have achieved strong ROIs in these dollars, as measured by incremental consumer purchases. We've also tested a higher levels of marketing with good results. With a 50% increase in media, we were able to deliver a double-digit increase in sales from most of the products we tested. At this time, we intend to add $20 million to our marketing programs in support of our core items, as well as new product innovation. This is an increase of 14% from 2009. Core items support will include ads that feature the anti-oxidant benefits of our super spices, our latest flavor forecast and first ever grilling-flavored forecast. The convenience of our dry seasoning mixes, the authentic ethnic flavors of brands such as Zatarain's, Thai Kitchen and Simply Asia and support for the Vahiné line in France. As shown on Slide 40, a large portion of the promotion and advertising behind product innovation will be concentrated on our national launch of Recipe Inspirations and Perfect Pinch here in the U.S. We are fueling these investments in our business with cost savings from CCI. Our goal in 2010 is to reduce cost of goods sold as well as SG&A expenses in the range of $35 million to $40 million. We have high confidence in this target with many initiatives already underway. These 2010 cost savings will fuel our incremental marketing support and help offset modest increases and input costs. Gross profit margin is projected to improve by at least 50 basis points, as a result of productivity and our continued shift toward a more favorable business mix. With incremental marketing support and our product innovation plans, we expect to grow sales 2% to 4% in local currency. Based on current rates, the impact of foreign currency will boost sales by 2% for a total projected increase of 4% to 6%. We've also added sales performance as a component of our operating divisions annual incentive compensation to bring increased focus.While healthy sales growth and margin expansion will drive profit growth in 2010, higher pension expense will be a headwind, as Gordon indicated, reducing EPS growth by about 3%. Taking this into account, we expect to achieve earnings per share in a $2.49 to $2.54 range. On a comparable basis for 2009, excluding the impact of restructuring charges recorded in 2009, this is a 6% to 8% increase. Note that no further restructuring charges are expected in 2010.We're looking for another year of excellent cash generation from our business, with higher profit and further reduction in our working capital. Our search for more great acquisitions to fold into our portfolio continues with a focus in Asia. Along with further pay down of our debt, acquisitions are our preferred use of cash in 2010. We have a number of interesting businesses on our radar screen, both in developed and emerging markets. Let me summarize so we can get to your questions. Our passion for flavor is the foundation of our success. Taste continues to rank first in what we choose to eat, ahead of quality, health and convenience. From premium gourmet items to the private label items we supply, our products offer consumers a good value, providing 90% of the flavor for meal and less than 10% of the cost. And we have long-term relationships with our customers who rely on McCormick for superior quality and service. With our marketing program lineup and innovation plans, McCormick's leadership team is excited about driving growth in 2010 on both the top line and the bottom line. It's the skill, energy and enthusiasm of McCormick employees around the world that give me confidence in the great performance and achievement of our financial goals for the year. Gordon and I look forward to reporting first quarter results with you in March and a more in-depth discussion at our Investor Conference in April. We thank our investors for your continued confidence and thank everyone on the call for your attention this morning. Now let's take some questions.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today is from the line of Alexia Howard with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today is from the line of Alexia Howard with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow-up on the topline growth in the Industrial segment. I think you said that quick-service restaurants domestically were pretty strong but at this time, it was the, I guess, sales at other food manufacturers that might have been slightl
componenttext: Just wanted to follow-up on the topline growth in the Industrial segment. I think you said that quick-service restaurants domestically were pretty strong but at this time, it was the, I guess, sales at other food manufacturers that might have been slightly lighter. And that may have been due to the timing of new product introductions. Could you talk a little bit about how that's likely to develop going forward with just the other timing of new products introductions happen to be like this quarter or can we expect that situation to continue?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we saw through a lot of 2009 was a focus by retailers in reducing SKUs and less of the ongoing line extension kinds of innovation that we've seen the last several years. What we're seeing is a pretty good innovation pipeline as everybody recognizes t
componenttext: What we saw through a lot of 2009 was a focus by retailers in reducing SKUs and less of the ongoing line extension kinds of innovation that we've seen the last several years. What we're seeing is a pretty good innovation pipeline as everybody recognizes that we got to have innovation to grow. So we are seeing a higher level of innovation activity. Now what I would expect to see and what we're seeing in the new products are more of the bigger, larger kinds of products, as opposed to smaller line extension kinds of products.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just a quick follow up, the commodity cost outlook, I know you got a lot of commodity-driven pricing in the Industrial segment. Across Consumer and Industrial, are we expecting commodity cost to remain up or how do you expect that to shape up goi
componenttext: And then just a quick follow up, the commodity cost outlook, I know you got a lot of commodity-driven pricing in the Industrial segment. Across Consumer and Industrial, are we expecting commodity cost to remain up or how do you expect that to shape up going forward?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're expecting commodity cost to be relatively benign through the year, we may start to see some uptick towards the later half of the year. Certainly in more of the Industrial side commodities, just to remind you, those tend to be a pass-through. So as w
componenttext: We're expecting commodity cost to be relatively benign through the year, we may start to see some uptick towards the later half of the year. Certainly in more of the Industrial side commodities, just to remind you, those tend to be a pass-through. So as we see changes in dairy or wheat or soybean oil, we'll pass those through as prices go up. And we'll pass them through as they come down. And we've seen more moderation through the back half of last year and what we expect to see through the first half of this year.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Rob Moskow with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Rob Moskow with Crédit Suisse.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was intrigued by your comment about acquisitions and a focus on Asia. I do remember back at an Analyst Day in 2007, where, I think it was Bob Lawless said, you're going to try to focus more on emerging market acquisition targets, but really nothing has
componenttext: I was intrigued by your comment about acquisitions and a focus on Asia. I do remember back at an Analyst Day in 2007, where, I think it was Bob Lawless said, you're going to try to focus more on emerging market acquisition targets, but really nothing has materialized in the last couple of years. Alan, can you talk a little bit about like the obstacles you face in trying to find suitable targets in these markets? And why you think you might be able to have more success this year?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, typically, the targets in those markets tend to be family businesses that have grown up and there's a point in the lifecycle where the owner decides it's time to move on. What we saw in -- really in 2007, 2008 were price expectations in emerging mark
componenttext: Yes, typically, the targets in those markets tend to be family businesses that have grown up and there's a point in the lifecycle where the owner decides it's time to move on. What we saw in -- really in 2007, 2008 were price expectations in emerging markets that were, in our view, too rich. And so we did not bring any of those to close. Now what we're seeing is a combination of more realism and expectations by owners and a lot of the folks that we've developed long relationships with, because our process is as much as possible we're going to develop relationships, get to know people and at a point, we'll be able to convince them that we're a good partner. And we're seeing more progress along that than we've seen the last couple of years.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Are there a lot of bidders for these types of assets? And do you think your relationships are better than the other bidders?
componenttext: Are there a lot of bidders for these types of assets? And do you think your relationships are better than the other bidders?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Some things are more announced as public auctions with investment bankers and more of a process. And in those cases, we really have to look hard to see if those are strategic for us. We typically tend to focus on developing longer-term relationships with
componenttext: Some things are more announced as public auctions with investment bankers and more of a process. And in those cases, we really have to look hard to see if those are strategic for us. We typically tend to focus on developing longer-term relationships with owners, so that we're not so much in a process.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Eric Serotta with Consumer Edge Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Eric Serotta with Consumer Edge Research.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to circle back on your top line growth targets for this year. It seems as the upper end of the range, 4%, it seems kind of aggressive to me, especially when you look at your core consumer volumes that were basically flat or down all year. And
componenttext: Just wanted to circle back on your top line growth targets for this year. It seems as the upper end of the range, 4%, it seems kind of aggressive to me, especially when you look at your core consumer volumes that were basically flat or down all year. And I know you went through some of the reasons why they were down for the year. But could you give us some color as to why you think that the upper end of that range should be achievable with especially with at least in Americas consumer, you're making the comment that you're not expecting much pricing?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. We typically, in normal years, we get a good bit of growth from new product innovation. And in 2009, much more of our organizational focus in the Americas was on the Lawry's integration. So we didn't have a lot of new product innovations that we wo
componenttext: Right. We typically, in normal years, we get a good bit of growth from new product innovation. And in 2009, much more of our organizational focus in the Americas was on the Lawry's integration. So we didn't have a lot of new product innovations that we would typically have. As you've seen by the support that we've shown, we are aggressively driving Recipe Inspirations and Perfect Pinch and supporting those in a pretty big way. We also are counting on a continued growth of Lawry's, as well as continued growth of our core businesses. And we're supporting that with advertising as well. So that's the reason that we centered on that guidance. We don't expect that we're going to spend the advertising money and not get some response.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: 4% seems like a pretty steep target even with a sizable $20 million increase in advertising. But I guess, you've seen some nice lift to date. Another thing, did I hear you correctly in response to the first question that some of your customer innovation i
componenttext: 4% seems like a pretty steep target even with a sizable $20 million increase in advertising. But I guess, you've seen some nice lift to date. Another thing, did I hear you correctly in response to the first question that some of your customer innovation is now focused on larger projects, rather then closed-in, it seemed to be the opposite all year. I just want to make sure that there was a -- see if there was a change?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, what we're seeing is less and less of the line extension kinds of innovation. There's certainly still work being done on taking sodium and reducing sodium and adding flavor. But what we are seeing is in terms of innovation, more significant innovatio
componenttext: Yes, what we're seeing is less and less of the line extension kinds of innovation. There's certainly still work being done on taking sodium and reducing sodium and adding flavor. But what we are seeing is in terms of innovation, more significant innovation is where our pipeline is stacking up right now.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that's changed over the past quarter or two? Because if I remember correctly, at least you talked about your industrial customers getting a bit more conservative and focusing more on closed-in innovation. And maybe this is going back more than a quart
componenttext: And that's changed over the past quarter or two? Because if I remember correctly, at least you talked about your industrial customers getting a bit more conservative and focusing more on closed-in innovation. And maybe this is going back more than a quarter or two, maybe it's going back a year. But it seems like most of this year, the focus was on closer-in [ph] things, have your customers become more aggressive in what they are looking at in terms of innovation or is this really just the same as you've seen all year?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's more of the theme that we've seen all year, where there's not as much room for minor innovation as retail customers have done more SKU reductions and more of a focus on thing -- we need to be truly innovative. I think everybody's struggling w
componenttext: I think it's more of the theme that we've seen all year, where there's not as much room for minor innovation as retail customers have done more SKU reductions and more of a focus on thing -- we need to be truly innovative. I think everybody's struggling with top line growth in the industry and I think there's a recognition that innovation is what's going to drive that growth.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Ken Goldman with JPMorgan Chase.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Ken Goldman with JPMorgan Chase.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I have a similar question to Eric Serotta's. Just hoping to understand a little bit about your visibility into some of the drivers of the consumer top line. It seems like there's an unusual number of upside and downside risks this year. You're goi
componenttext: I guess I have a similar question to Eric Serotta's. Just hoping to understand a little bit about your visibility into some of the drivers of the consumer top line. It seems like there's an unusual number of upside and downside risks this year. You're going into your first period in a couple of years without any pricing, perhaps. There's a little bit of a channel shift, which I know is not a huge deal to manage but it's something. There may be some additional pressure for SKU rationalization, and then of course the Wal-Mart decision, I believe, is still pending, which could be a positive or a negative. So just wondering when you look at all those, how much confidence you have in the numbers that you're putting out there and maybe you can give us some of that confidence as well?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we feel like we have the right programs, certainly, to hit the numbers that we put out there. Again, because we have a renewed focus on product innovation and we expect to see benefits from that. You're right, there are a lot of moving parts in the
componenttext: Well, we feel like we have the right programs, certainly, to hit the numbers that we put out there. Again, because we have a renewed focus on product innovation and we expect to see benefits from that. You're right, there are a lot of moving parts in the business this year. And certainly, we're not going to speculate on what's going to happen. But we think most of the SKU rationalization that we expected to see, we've seen. And that has, by and large, not had a significant impact because the products that have been reduced, haven't been major sellers. And as well, what we've seen is as retailers have reduced space, they've tended to reduce the space for more of the smaller regional brands. There's no question that the top line is going to be a continued -- a lot of pressure in the top line as the economy continues to struggle but we have pretty good faith that we've got the right programs to grow our business.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Chris Growe with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Chris Growe with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: In your targets for the year, sales and EPS, do you incorporate acquisitions this year? Especially given you've got a -- something like a pretty good pipeline of deals in the works?
componenttext: In your targets for the year, sales and EPS, do you incorporate acquisitions this year? Especially given you've got a -- something like a pretty good pipeline of deals in the works?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've not put any of that into the forecast.
componenttext: We've not put any of that into the forecast.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I want to be clear on kind of the marketing investment, so this $20 billion increase you had in '09 did that shift throughout the year, maybe more to coupons and price-based support from say, advertising as the consumer was quite weak and I guess I'm just
componenttext: I want to be clear on kind of the marketing investment, so this $20 billion increase you had in '09 did that shift throughout the year, maybe more to coupons and price-based support from say, advertising as the consumer was quite weak and I guess I'm just trying to get a feel for what happens in 2010, should we see a lot of that shifting occurring as well? Is that all incorporated in that number you gave us of up $20 million?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, coupons and promotional pricing comes right out of between growth and net sales. So that wouldn't be at all in that spending. There would be some in-store kinds of activities that could be in there or specific consumer kinds of promotions. But it's by
componenttext: No, coupons and promotional pricing comes right out of between growth and net sales. So that wouldn't be at all in that spending. There would be some in-store kinds of activities that could be in there or specific consumer kinds of promotions. But it's by and large, media advertising.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So we've seen an even bigger increase in support in 2010. Are you having to invest more heavily in, say, price-based marketing, whatever you want to call it, in addition to what you're doing on the actual marketing line, the media?
componenttext: So we've seen an even bigger increase in support in 2010. Are you having to invest more heavily in, say, price-based marketing, whatever you want to call it, in addition to what you're doing on the actual marketing line, the media?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've certainly increased our coupons and as we always do, work with customers on getting the right promotions. Chris, one thing I did want to correct, not correct but add color to, this year's $20 million increase included about $14 million incremen
componenttext: Yes, we've certainly increased our coupons and as we always do, work with customers on getting the right promotions. Chris, one thing I did want to correct, not correct but add color to, this year's $20 million increase included about $14 million incremental from Lawry's.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just looking at the gross margin you had, obviously, a lot of cost savings coming through that was even above your target you even gave last quarter. Was that the main driver, the upside there? I'm looking at volumes being soft this year across the busine
componenttext: Just looking at the gross margin you had, obviously, a lot of cost savings coming through that was even above your target you even gave last quarter. Was that the main driver, the upside there? I'm looking at volumes being soft this year across the business, what really drove the gross margin this quarter, it was a good bit above my expectations?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Cost savings did come in above expectations as we were talking about a $35 million and then ended up being closer, over $40 million as we reported. But the business mix also was a big driver as well because the Consumer business grew within the quarter an
componenttext: Cost savings did come in above expectations as we were talking about a $35 million and then ended up being closer, over $40 million as we reported. But the business mix also was a big driver as well because the Consumer business grew within the quarter and the Industrial business was actually down in the quarter. So that'll be a driver to the gross margin as well.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: But in terms of like input cost overall, would that have been a major factor for the quarter?
componenttext: But in terms of like input cost overall, would that have been a major factor for the quarter?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, input cost would not have been a major factor.
componenttext: No, input cost would not have been a major factor.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Ann Gurkin with Davenport & Company.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Ann Gurkin with Davenport & Company.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can start in the U.K., if you can help me understand, are you making any changes to your strategy in the U.K. given the continued very challenging environment?
componenttext: I was wondering if you can start in the U.K., if you can help me understand, are you making any changes to your strategy in the U.K. given the continued very challenging environment?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not in terms of major strategies but what we are continuing to do is focus on new product innovation and supporting the brands there with a little bit different messaging focused on value. The U.K. is, admittedly, one of the toughest markets that we have
componenttext: Not in terms of major strategies but what we are continuing to do is focus on new product innovation and supporting the brands there with a little bit different messaging focused on value. The U.K. is, admittedly, one of the toughest markets that we have in the world in terms of growth but in terms of a large change in strategy, no.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Switching over to Asia, with the added business customers, do you need to add capacity or make any investment in that market?
componenttext: Switching over to Asia, with the added business customers, do you need to add capacity or make any investment in that market?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Only in terms of sales capacity, we continued to de-bottleneck our manufacturing facilities. And so we're not making a significant capital investment to increase that at this point.
componenttext: Only in terms of sales capacity, we continued to de-bottleneck our manufacturing facilities. And so we're not making a significant capital investment to increase that at this point.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Mitch Pinheiro with Janney Montgomery Scott.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Mitch Pinheiro with Janney Montgomery Scott.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about your pricing outlook for the consumer, particularly the U.S. Consumer business and the Industrial business?
componenttext: Can you talk about your pricing outlook for the consumer, particularly the U.S. Consumer business and the Industrial business?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our forecast right now doesn't call for any significant pricing or for any significant change in input cost. We believe the moderate input cost inflation that we'll see, that will impact the Consumer business in general, will be able to offset with produc
componenttext: Our forecast right now doesn't call for any significant pricing or for any significant change in input cost. We believe the moderate input cost inflation that we'll see, that will impact the Consumer business in general, will be able to offset with productivity and cost savings. Now if something changes later in the year, we'll certainly respond to that but what we're seeing right now is a more benign pricing environment.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of sort of the difference, consumer channel segmentation, is there are pricing pressure or mix pressure as a results of that in 2010?
componenttext: In terms of sort of the difference, consumer channel segmentation, is there are pricing pressure or mix pressure as a results of that in 2010?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've seen certainly, mix pressure in 2009 as we've seen more sales go to our dry seasoning mixes products as oppose to our gourmet products. We expected, we don't expected a continued shift in that kind of mix. We think we saw the worst of it in 2009. Bu
componenttext: We've seen certainly, mix pressure in 2009 as we've seen more sales go to our dry seasoning mixes products as oppose to our gourmet products. We expected, we don't expected a continued shift in that kind of mix. We think we saw the worst of it in 2009. But we don't expect there to be a lot of need or opportunity for increased pricing or decreased pricing in 2010.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: You've had changes in your shelf sets, the gravity feeds that was the initiative, I guess, that happened over the last two years. Is there any -- just seems to have lost momentum or just not a focus? Or maybe I'm wrong if you could just update us on sort
componenttext: You've had changes in your shelf sets, the gravity feeds that was the initiative, I guess, that happened over the last two years. Is there any -- just seems to have lost momentum or just not a focus? Or maybe I'm wrong if you could just update us on sort of what you're doing from the in-store merchandising and shelf space?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of our shelf, we're still very happy with the gravity feed, merchandising sets that we've had. They continue to make it easy for the consumer shop, easy to stock for the retailers. So we're still very happy with that. We are continuing to focus o
componenttext: In terms of our shelf, we're still very happy with the gravity feed, merchandising sets that we've had. They continue to make it easy for the consumer shop, easy to stock for the retailers. So we're still very happy with that. We are continuing to focus on finding more opportunities for displays in other parts of the store, and have continued to expand our presence in meat sections with displays and that sort of things. So there's not a major merchandising initiative this year other than finding the space and there are appropriate merchandising for Recipe Inspirations, which we think is not only going to do very well as a product line itself, but is also going to have a pretty high conversion rate to people buying the bottles for the spices that they find in those packets.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Would that be positive margin mix for you in that trade?
componenttext: Would that be positive margin mix for you in that trade?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's more of a neutral margin mix. The key thing though that we're trying to achieve with that is to make it easier for people to continue to cook and discover how easy and great it is with using spice ingredients.
componenttext: It's more of a neutral margin mix. The key thing though that we're trying to achieve with that is to make it easier for people to continue to cook and discover how easy and great it is with using spice ingredients.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Relative to inventories coming out of the holiday cooking season, any comments with regard to that?
componenttext: Relative to inventories coming out of the holiday cooking season, any comments with regard to that?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we think the in-store inventories, at the end of the holiday season, were lower this year than they were in past years. And that's just based on our measure of what our factory sales were, as compared to what we saw in the measured channels.
componenttext: Yes, we think the in-store inventories, at the end of the holiday season, were lower this year than they were in past years. And that's just based on our measure of what our factory sales were, as compared to what we saw in the measured channels.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from the line of Eric Katzman with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is from the line of Eric Katzman with Deutsche Bank.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can I get an explanation as to the difference between the media or sort of brand marketing spending that you referenced in the press release, I think it was $147 million this year, versus let's say, the $57 million or 60-something million that you, I gues
componenttext: Can I get an explanation as to the difference between the media or sort of brand marketing spending that you referenced in the press release, I think it was $147 million this year, versus let's say, the $57 million or 60-something million that you, I guess you put in your 10-K? Where's the $100 million or $90 million?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: One is pure advertising and one is consumer promotion but that consumer promotion is not price reduction as Alan said earlier, it's consumer promotion that goes directly in front of the consumer. So it could be sampling events, it could be feature items,
componenttext: One is pure advertising and one is consumer promotion but that consumer promotion is not price reduction as Alan said earlier, it's consumer promotion that goes directly in front of the consumer. So it could be sampling events, it could be feature items, in-store displays, so all of that is right in front of the consumers. It's not price promotion, which would be between gross and net.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the 140-something million, that's all deduction from SG&A?
componenttext: So the 140-something million, that's all deduction from SG&A?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: That is correct. That is all on the SG&A line.
componenttext: That is correct. That is all on the SG&A line.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And do you think that, that, because when I look at your, let's say, your pure media advertising number that you list, I'm not sure what it was for '09, I only have the '08 number, which was 57, that's like 3% of your Consumer businesses sales, which is p
componenttext: And do you think that, that, because when I look at your, let's say, your pure media advertising number that you list, I'm not sure what it was for '09, I only have the '08 number, which was 57, that's like 3% of your Consumer businesses sales, which is pretty low to the rest of the industry. So do you think that the $140 million is equivalent to what other people listed their advertising in their 8-K? Or is it apples-and-oranges?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't have the scientific study in front of me here, Eric. But I do know when we look at that type of disclosure, we wanted to make sure we were consistent in the industry. We also wanted to make sure we're accurately portraying what our dollars are doi
componenttext: I don't have the scientific study in front of me here, Eric. But I do know when we look at that type of disclosure, we wanted to make sure we were consistent in the industry. We also wanted to make sure we're accurately portraying what our dollars are doing and how they're working for us. And those dollars that are, what we call consumer promotional dollars, are volume-driven events that do have a benefit, as opposed to some perhaps a price reduction, which you'll see on the top line in net sales. So I would think other food manufacturers would view that similarly, a sampling event or anything that's trying to get the consumer to buy your product should be an SG&A item. So we're certainly in conformity with GAAP on our disclosure, that's for sure.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess what I'm getting at is if we assume that it's apples-to-apples, your advertising to sales of just the Consumer business, just seems low relative to the peers. And as industrial gets to be a smaller and smaller percentage of the company, it seems t
componenttext: I guess what I'm getting at is if we assume that it's apples-to-apples, your advertising to sales of just the Consumer business, just seems low relative to the peers. And as industrial gets to be a smaller and smaller percentage of the company, it seems to me that the ratio is even more important, then perhaps that explains why there was some disappointment in the top line in the U.S. business this year?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your point's well taken, Eric, we still have a relatively low advertising to sales ratio in our Consumer business. And that's why we continue to try to increase that and get it up to more competitive levels. I would remind you that we still are about 90%
componenttext: Your point's well taken, Eric, we still have a relatively low advertising to sales ratio in our Consumer business. And that's why we continue to try to increase that and get it up to more competitive levels. I would remind you that we still are about 90% of the share voice in our category. But on a relative basis, compared to other's consumer packaged goods industry, we still look pretty low.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess it's pretty concentrated in the third and fourth quarter too, so maybe it's a little bigger percentage given the seasonality?
componenttext: I guess it's pretty concentrated in the third and fourth quarter too, so maybe it's a little bigger percentage given the seasonality?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our level of voice in the fourth quarter has continued to go up and that's because that's where we see the biggest impact. But we also spend in, in first and second quarters, we're building behind grilling and the other events. We've really focused our sp
componenttext: Our level of voice in the fourth quarter has continued to go up and that's because that's where we see the biggest impact. But we also spend in, in first and second quarters, we're building behind grilling and the other events. We've really focused our spending in the last couple of years behind grilling in holiday. This year will be a little different as we've expanded that to support the new product introductions.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just switching to the CCI program and the productivity efforts, that's also, I guess running -- you ramped that up since the restructuring a couple of years ago, but similarly, compared to some of the peers, it's only about, by my estimation, lik
componenttext: And then just switching to the CCI program and the productivity efforts, that's also, I guess running -- you ramped that up since the restructuring a couple of years ago, but similarly, compared to some of the peers, it's only about, by my estimation, like 2% of COGS. And it looks like the peer group is doing much bigger, let's say, productivity levels. And so I wanted you to just kind of touch on that. Do you benchmark versus the peer group? Is it a function of scale that may be is why a General Mills or a Kellogg's is taking, whatever, 4% to 5% of COGS out every year? What do you think?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're trying to understand the definition, difference between what we're calling costs CCI versus, for instance, General Mill's Holistic Margin Management, so that we are capturing and not disadvantaging ourselves. We've hired actually a consulting firm t
componenttext: We're trying to understand the definition, difference between what we're calling costs CCI versus, for instance, General Mill's Holistic Margin Management, so that we are capturing and not disadvantaging ourselves. We've hired actually a consulting firm to help us in; one, making sure that our program is ratcheted up and we're taking out all the cost that we can; and secondly, making sure that our definitions are consistent with what other people in the industry are doing.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And for clarity, Eric, I mean I've been accused to being a tough grader on this thing. So the only thing that gets in that number has to be supported and documented and has to be a year-over-year benefit that we can count on as a year-to-year change. So t
componenttext: And for clarity, Eric, I mean I've been accused to being a tough grader on this thing. So the only thing that gets in that number has to be supported and documented and has to be a year-over-year benefit that we can count on as a year-to-year change. So things like productivity improvements that releases capacity doesn't get into a CCI number, although that unleashes a volume opportunity, it's not a year-over-year reduction in cost. So that's to Alan's point. We're still trying to get our arms around our definition relative to others to make sure we're not unduly penalizing ourselves as we report these numbers.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the M&A side, I mean I don't remember the company talking so publicly about being so close to M&A. And you said, I think to Mitch or to Chris, that your assumptions don't include any M&A. But can you kind of go through your financial criteria, as to wh
componenttext: On the M&A side, I mean I don't remember the company talking so publicly about being so close to M&A. And you said, I think to Mitch or to Chris, that your assumptions don't include any M&A. But can you kind of go through your financial criteria, as to what type of M&A is going to get done? I mean does it have to be ROIC accretive in a year or two, just maybe go through some of the financial metrics?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'd like to be EPS accretive by the second full year and EVA positive by the second full year, is the way we tend to think about it. The financial change or the accounting changes where we now have to expense deal cost make first-year accretion a lot tou
componenttext: We'd like to be EPS accretive by the second full year and EVA positive by the second full year, is the way we tend to think about it. The financial change or the accounting changes where we now have to expense deal cost make first-year accretion a lot tougher. But we tend to think about it as being accretive by the second year.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So you're including any deal cost in the dilution in the first year?
componenttext: So you're including any deal cost in the dilution in the first year?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is the Board ambivalent as to whether it's equity or debt or cash? I mean, if one of these families wanted equity, is that okay?
componenttext: Is the Board ambivalent as to whether it's equity or debt or cash? I mean, if one of these families wanted equity, is that okay?

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've not done any equity deals.
componenttext: We've not done any equity deals.

headline: McCormick & Co. Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our purpose is for a cash or a debt deal. I mean, certainly if there was a structure that require equity that we felt was the right for our shareholders and right for that deal structure, we would consider it. But our preference is to do cash deals.
componenttext: Our purpose is for a cash or a debt deal. I mean, certainly if there was a structure that require equity that we felt was the right for our shareholders and right for that deal structure, we would consider it. But our preference is to do cash deals.
